div.head: PREFACE.
div.p: This Drama is in no sense a translation, and ought not, I think, in fairness to be called even an adaptation of Victor Hugo's fine play "Le Roi s'Amuse."

It originated in a request made to me by one of our most popular actors, to turn the libretto of Rigoletto into a play, as he wished to act the part of the jester. On looking at Victor Hugo's drama, with this object, I found so much in it that seemed to me inadmissible on our stage—so much, besides, that was wanting in dramatic motive and cohesion, and,—I say it in all humility—so much that was defective in that central secret of stage effect, climax, that I determined to take the situation of the jester and his daughter, and to recast in my own way the incidents in which their story was invested.

The death of Galeotto Manfredi at the hands of his wife Francesca Bentivoglio is historical. It seemed to me that the atmosphere of a petty Italian Court of the Fifteenth Century was well suited, as a medium for presenting the jester's wrongs, his rooted purpose of revenge, and the miscarriage of that purpose.

I should not have thought it necessary to say thus much, had not some of the newspaper critics talked of my work as a simple translation of Victor Hugo's drama, while others
described it, more contemptuously, as a mere rifaciamento of Verdi's libretto.
Those who will take the trouble to compare my work with either of its alleged originals, will see that my play is neither translation nor rifaciamento.

The motives of Bertuccio, the machinery by which his revenge is diverted from its intended channel, and the action in the court subsequent to the carrying off of his daughter, are my own, and I conceive that these features give me the fullest right to call the "Fool's Revenge" a new play, even if the use of Victor Hugo's Triboulet and Blanche disentitle it to the epithet "original"—which is matter of opinion.

For the admirable manner in which the drama is mounted and represented at Sadler's Wells, and for the peculiarly powerful impersonation of Bertuccio, I owe all gratitude to Mr. Phelps. I must extend that feeling also to Miss Heath, Miss Atkinson, and the rest of the Sadler's Wells Company engaged in the representation of the "Fool's Revenge."

div.head: Costumes.
div.p: At Sadler's Wells the costume and scenery of this play were appropriate to the period of Francis the First, which is some years later than the actual date of Manfredi's murder. This departure from strict chronology is unobjectionable, when, as at Sadler's Wells, strict consistency is maintained in the dresses, architecture, and decoration of the piece.

In strict propriety, the costume of the Duke and nobles should consist of short, brightly-coloured jerkins, reaching just below the waist, with rather full sleeves, slashed, and confined at the wrists, embroidered belts round the waist, coloured tight hose, often worn of a different colour in the two legs, and velvet shoes. Short mantles may be worn by the young nobles. Ascolti, Malatesta, and the elder guests, may, with propriety, wear long velvet or silk gowns, of purple, crimson, or other rich colours, with borders of fur.

The hair should be worn full and long, in the style familiar to us from Raphael's earlier pictures. The head-dress of the younger men is a small coloured velvet cap, with a raised edge, often scalloped, and ornamented with a chain and medal.

The Fool, of course, wears a motley suit, with a hood like that worn by Shakespeare's fools. His second dress should be a long gown, of sober colour. Fiordelisa's dress should be white, or dove-coloured, with scalloped sleeves and a tight body. The Duchess's costume, of the same cut, should be of velvet, slashed, and embroidered with gold. She may wear a gold net; a silk, or chenille net, would also be appropriate to Fiordelisa.

div.stage: SCENE.—The Stage represents a Loggia opening on the Gardens of Manfredi's Palace; a low terrace at the back, and beyond, a view of the City and country adjacent. Moonlight. The Gardens and Loggia illuminated for a festa.
NOBLES and LADIES discovered R. and C., and moving through the gardens and loggia. Music at a distance.TORELLI and ORDELAFFI discovered—Enter ASCOLTI, L.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Messer Bernardo, you shall judge between us—
Is Ordelaffi's here, a feasting face?
I say, 'tis fitter for a funeral.

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: An Ordelaffi scarce can love the feast
That greets Octavian Riario,
Lord of Forlì and Imola.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: Because our line were masters there of old,
Till they were fools enough to get pulled down?
I was born to no lordship but my sword.
Thanks to my stout black bands, I look to win
New titles, and so grieve not over lost ones.
My glove upon't! I'll prove a lighter dancer,
A lustier wooer, and a deeper drinker,
Than e'er a landed lordling of you all.
Is it a wager?

div.stage: (GINEVRA passes with MANFREDI from L. to R., MALATESTA appears L. watching them)

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: My hand to that! There's Malatesta's wife,
The fair Ginevra. Let's try lucks with her?

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: 'Ware hawk! Grey Guido's an old-fashioned husband;
Look how he glares upon the Lord Manfredi,
Each of his soft words to the fair Ginevra 's
A dagger in the old fool's heart.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: Sublime! ripe sixty wedded to sixteen,
And thinks to shut the foxes from his grapes!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: The Duke, too, for his rival! Poor old man!

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: Let the Duke look to it. Ginevra's smiles
May breed him worse foes than Count Malatesta.
(whispering) The Duchess!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Faith 'tis ill rousing Bentivoglio blood.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: And she's as jealous as her own pet greyhound.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: And sharper in the teeth. I wonder much
She leaves Faenza, knowing her Manfredi
So general a lover.

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: She leaves Faenza?

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: So they say: to-morrow
Rides to Bologna to her grim old father,
Giovanni Bentivoglio.

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: To complain
Of her hot-blooded husband?

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Nay, I know not—
Enough, she goes, and fair dame as she is
A murrain go with her, say I. There never
Was good time in Faenza, since she came
To spoil sport with her jealousy. Manfredi
Will be himself again, when she is hence.

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: Hush! here she comes—

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: With that misshapen imp
Bertuccio. Gibing devil! I shall thrust
My dagger down his throat one of these days!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Call him a jester; he laughs vitriol!

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: Spares nothing: cracks his random scurril quips
Upon my master—great Lorenzo's self.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: Do the knave justice, he's a king of tongue-fence;
Not a weak joint in all our armours round,
But he knows, and can hit. Confound the rogue!
I'm blistered still from a word-basting he
Gave me but yesterday. Would we were quits!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Wait! I've a rod in pickle that shall flay
The tough hide off his hump. A rare revenge!

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: They're here—avoid!

div.stage: (ASCOLTI, ORDELAFFI, and TORELLI retire up C. and mingle with the GUESTS)
Enter FRANCESCA and BERTUCCIO, R., followed by her two WOMEN.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: (looking off, as if watching, and to herself) Still with her! changing hot palms and long looks!
Her's for the dance—her's at the feast—all her's!
Nothing for me but shallow courtesies,
And hollow coin of compliment that leaves
The craving heart as empty as a beggar
Bemocked with counters!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (counting on his fingers, and looking at the moon) Moon—Manfredi—moon!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ha, knave!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: By your leave, Monna Cecca, I am cyphering.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Some fool's sum?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Yes; running your husband's changes
Against the moon's. Manfredi has it hollow.
It comes out ten new loves 'gainst five new moons!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Where do I stand?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: First of the ten; your moon was a whole honey one;
Excluding that, it's nine loves to four moons.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You pity me, Bertuccio?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Not a whit;
I pity sparrows, but not sparrow-hawks.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I read your riddle. I am strong enough
To right my own wrongs! So I am, while here.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Then stay!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My father at Bologna looks for me.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Then go!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And leave him here—with her—both free,
And not a friend that I can trust to watch
And give me due report how things go 'twixt them.
Had I one friend—

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: You have Bertuccio.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Men call you faithless, bitter, loving wrong
For wrong's sake, Duke Manfredi's worst councillor,
Still prompting him to evil.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: How folks flatter!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How, then, am I to trust you?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Monna Cecca,
You know the wild beasts that your husband keeps
Down in the castle fosse? There's a she-leopard
I lie and gaze at by the hour together;
So sleek, so graceful, and so dangerous!
I long to see her let loose on a man.
Trust me to draw the bolt, and loose my leopard.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I'll trust your love of mischief, not of me.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: That's safest!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I must know how fares this fancy
Of Duke Manfredi for yon pale Ginevra—
Mark him and her—their meetings—communings;
I know you're private with my lord.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (with a dry chuckle) He trusts me!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Here! take my ring: your letters sealed with this,
My page Ascanio will bring me straight;
'Tis but three hours' hard riding—and in six
I'm here again. Mark! write not on suspicion,
Let evil thought ripen to evil act;
That in the full flush of their guilty joys
I may strike sudden, and strike home.
No Bentivoglio pardons.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Have a care!
Faenza is Manfredi's! These court-flies, (pointing to the GUESTS)
Who flutter in the sunshine of his favour,
Have stings: the pudding-headed citizens
Love his free ways: he leaves their wives alone—
You play your own head, touching his.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Give me my vengeance. Then come what come may.
Enough—I am resolved. Now for the dance!
They shall not see a cloud upon my brow,
Though my heart ache and burn. I can smile too,
On him and her—Bertuccio, remember!

div.stage: Exit FRANCESCA, followed by her women, R.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (looking at the ring) A blood-stone—apt reminder! Does she think
That none but she have wrongs? That none but she
Mean to revenge them? What? "No Bentivoglio
Pardons." There is a certain vile Bertuccio,
A twisted, withered, hunch-backed, court buffoon—
A thing to make mirth, and to be made mirth of—
A something betwixt ape and man, that claims
To run in couples with your ladyship.
You hunt Manfredi—I hunt Malatesta—
Let's try which of the two has sharper fangs!

div.stage: MANFREDI and GINEVRA appear in the background, R.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: The Duke and Malatesta's wife! (he retires up)

div.stage: MANFREDI and GINEVRA come forward, MALATESTA watching them, L.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Not yet!—but one more round! The feast is blank
For me when you are gone. The flowers lack perfume,
Missing your fragrant breath. The music sounds
Harsh and untunable, when your sweet voice
Makes no more under-melody. Oh stay!

sp.speaker: Ginev.
sp.l: I am summoned, sir—my husband waits for me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What spoil-sports are these husbands (aside) and these wives!
Per Bacco! I could wish Count Malatesta
Would lend my duchess escort to Bologna,
So were we both well rid.

sp.speaker: Ginev.
sp.l: Your pardon, sir.
My husband beckons. It is I, not you,
Must bear his moods to-night—I dare not stay.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I would not bring a cloud to your fair brow
For all Faenza. Fare you well, sweet lady!
I render up your jewel, Malatesta;
See that you guard it as befits its price.

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: Trust me for that, my lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: (to GINEVRA) Sweet dreams wait on you.

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: (aside) This night sees her safe past Faenza's walls;
She's too fair for this liquorish court of ours.

div.stage: Exeunt MALATESTA and GINEVRA, L.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: A peerless lady!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (coming forward) And a churlish spouse!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Bertuccio!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: "At your elbow, sir," quoth Satanus.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Come, fool, let's rail at husbands.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Shall I call
Your wife to help us?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Out on thee, screech-owl!
Just when I felt my chains about to fall,
Thou mind'st me of my jailor. Thank the saints,
I shall be free to-morrow for a while—
I'm thirsty to employ my liberty.
Come, my familiar, help me to some mischief—
Some pleasant devilry, with just the spice
Of sin to make the enjoyment exquisite!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Let's see!—throat-cutting's pleasant—but that's stale;
Plotting has savour in it—but 'tis too tedious;
Say, a campaign with Ordelaffi's band,
So you may feed all the seven sins at once!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Out, barren hound! thy wits are growing dull.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: A man can't always be finding out new sins;
Think, they're as hard to hit on as new pleasures.
My head on't, Alexander had not run
So wide a round of pleasures, as you of sins;
And yet he offered kingdoms for a new one.
You must invoke Asmodeus, not Beelzebub.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: The devil specially charged with love;
He has more work than all the infernal legion.
There's Malatesta's wife—she's young, and fair,
And good, they say;—rare matter for sin there,
Though 'tis the oldest of them all.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But show me
How to win her! She's cold as she is fair;
I have spent enough sweet speech to have softened stone,
And all in vain.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: The monks say Hannibal
Melted the rocks with vinegar—not sugar.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But she is adamant!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: When all else fails
You've still force to fall back on. Carry her off
From under Guido's grizzled beard.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: By Bacchus,
There's mettle in thy counsel, knave! I'll think on't.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: It needs no brains neither—only strong hands
And hard hearts. Here come both.

div.stage: Enter TORELLI, ASCOLTI, and ORDELAFFI, C.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What say you, gentlemen; may I trust your arms?

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: They're yours in any quarrel.

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: So are mine!

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: And mine!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: One at a time. You said "arms!"—Of Torelli
You should ask legs! His did such famous service
In carrying him out of danger at Sarzana,
I think they may be trusted.

div.stage: (all laugh except TORELLI)

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Scurril knave!
But I'll be even with thee.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: That were pity.
A hump would be a sore disfigurement
Upon a back that you're so fond of showing!

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: This rogue needs gagging.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (to ASCOLTI) What! for speaking truth?
I cry you mercy—I forgot how ugly
It must sound to a Florentine Ambassador!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Well thrust, Bertuccio?

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: (angrily) My lord, my lord!
The slave is paid to find us wit—

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (interrupting) Hold there.
No man is bound to impossibilities—
'Tis a known maxim of the Roman law;
How then can I find wit for Ordelaffi?

div.stage: (all laugh but ORDELAFFI)

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: But look—there's Serafino—big with a sonnet:
I must help him to reason for his rhymes!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Stay!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Not I! You're for finding out new sins;
With three such councillors, I am superfluous.
(aside) The evil seed is sown—'twill grow—'twill grow.

div.stage: Exit BERTUCCIO.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Toad!

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: Foul-mouthed scoffer!

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: Warped in wit and limb!

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: My lord, you give your monkey too much rope,
He'll soon forget all tricks in the scurvy one
Of making his grinders meet in our soft parts.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Nay, give the devil his due; if he hits hard,
He hits impartially. I take my share
Of buffets with the rest. Best cure the smart
By laughing at your neighbour that smarts worse;
But about this business, where your arms may help me.

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: Is it an enemy to be silenced?

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: A castle
To be surprised? A merchant to be squeezed?

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: Or aught in which ducats, or brains, of Florence
Can help?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: No.—Who was queen of the feast to-night?
In your skilled judgment, Messer Gian Maria?

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: I ought to say, your duchess, fair Francesca;
But, if another tongue had asked the question—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Speak out thy honest judgment!

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: Not a lady
In all Faenza's worthy to compare
With proud Ginevra Malatesta!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: I think I know a fairer,—but no matter!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I hold with Ordelaffi.—I have mounted
Ginevra's colours in my cap, and heart;
But she's too proud, or fearful of old Guido,
To smile upon my suit.—'Tis the first time
I've found so coy a dame.

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: Trust one who knows them—
The coyest are not always chastest.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: How say you, if I spared her shame of yielding
By a night escalade?

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: (shaking his head) Carry her off?
A Malatesta? Were it an enemy's town—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Hear him!—how modestly he talks!—Why, man,
Since when shrank'st thou from climbing balconies,
And forcing doors without an invitation?

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: Oh, citizens', I grant you—but a noble's,—
One of ourselves—

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: Remember, Malatesta
Is cousin to the old Lord of Cesena;—
The affair might breed a feud, and so let in
The sly Venetian.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Be advised, my lord;
If you must breathe your new-fledged liberty,
Try safer game! Old Malatesta's horns
Might prove too sharp for pastime!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Out, you faint hearts!
Do you fall off? Then, by St. Francis' bones,
I and Bertuccio will adventure it.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Bertuccio! My jewel to his hump;
'Twas he put this mad frolic in your head.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And if it were? At least he'll stand by me:
Perchance his wits may be worth all your brawn.

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: Here comes one who may claim to be consulted
Upon this business.

div.stage: Enter MALATESTA, L.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: (disconcerted) Guido Malatesta!
Why, how now, Count? You left our feast so soon,
I thought you warm i' the sheets this good half-hour.

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: I had forgot my duty to your lordship;
So now repair my lack of courtesy—
To-morrow I purpose riding to Cesena,
And would not go without due leave taking.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: (aside) This jumps well with my project. What, to-morrow!
You ride alone?

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: No, with my wife.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: (aside) The devil!
Why, this is sudden—she spoke no word of this
To-night!

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: Tush! women know not their own minds,
How should they know their husbands'?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But your reason?

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: Your air here in Faenza is too warm,
And scarce so pure as fits my wife's complexion;
She'll be better in my castle at Cesena;
The walls are five feet thick, and from the platform
There's a rare view. She'll need no exercise.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: (aside) The gaoler! (aloud) But what says the lady's will?

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: I never ask that; and so 'scape all risk
Of finding it run counter to my own.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Faenza will have great miss of you both.

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: Oh, fear not—I'll return; your wine's too good
To be left lightly. I'll be back to-morrow,
Before the gates are shut. Meanwhile accept
This leave-taking by proxy from my wife.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Not so; I must exchange farewell with her
To-morrow.

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: We shall start an hour ere dawn;—
You'll scarce be stirring.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: (aside) Plague upon the churl!
He meets me at all points. At least, I hope,
This absence of your wife will not be long;
My duchess cannot spare her. (aside) Saints forgive me!

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: When your fair lady wants her, she can send:
I'll answer for her coming on that summons.
Good night, sweet lords. (aside) How crest fall'n he looks!
Mass! 'tis ill cozening an old condottiere!
Did he think I had forgot to guard my baggage?

div.stage: Exit MALATESTA.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: A murrain go with him! May the horse stumble
That carries him, and break his old bull-neck!
Oh, this is cruel—with my hand stretched out
To have to draw't back empty! I could curse!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: What if I helped you to a substitute
For coy Ginevra? passing her in beauty,—
One, too, whose conquest puts no crown to risk,
And helps withal a notable requital
That we all owe Bertuccio, you included.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Guess what's happened to Bertruccio!

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: He's grown good-natured?

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: Or has dropp'd his hump?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: He has found a monkey uglier than himself?

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: No—something stranger than all these would be,
If they had happened;—he has found a mistress!

div.stage: (all burst out laughing)

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My lady's pet baboon? Bertuccio
Graced with a mistress! (he laughs)

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: She is blind, of course?

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: And has a hump, I hope, to match his own
What a rare breed 'twill be of two humped babes,
Like Bactrian camels!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Bertuccio with a mistress!—why the rogue
Ne'er yet made joke so monstrous, or so pleasant!

div.stage: (they laugh again)

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Laugh as you please, sirs—on my knightly faith,
He has a mistress and a rare one too!
Nay, if you doubt my word—Here comes Dell' Aquila—
He knows as well as I.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: We'll question him.

div.stage: Enter SERAFINO DELL' AQUILA, C.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Good even to my poet—you walk late!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: (pointing to the moon) I tend my mistress: poets and lunatics,
You know, are her liege subjects.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: They are happy!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: They have a new mistress every month,
And each month's mistress no two nights alike.
But jesters can find mistresses, it seems,
As well as poets. There's Torelli swears
Bertuccio has one, and that you know it.

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: I know he has a rare maid close mewed up,
But whether wife or daughter—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Tell not me!
A mistress for a thousand! But what of her?
How did you find her out?

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: 'Twas some weeks since,
Attending vespers in your house's chapel,
At San Costanza, I beheld a maiden
Kneeling before that picture of our lady,
By Fra Filippo—oh, so fair—so rapt
In her pure passionate prayers—I tell you, sirs,
I was nigh going on my knees beside her,
And asking for an interest in her orisons:
Such eyes of softest blue, crowned with such wreaths
Of glossy chesnut hair—a cheek of snow
Flushed tenderly, as when the sunlight strikes
Upon an evening alp, and overall,
A grace of maiden modesty that lay
More still and snowy round her than the folds
Of her white veil. And when she rose I rose,
And followed her like one drawn by a charm
To a mean house, where entering, she was lost.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: She was alone?

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Only a shrewish servant
That saw her to the church, and saw her home.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: A most weak wolf-dog for so choice a lamb!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Methought, my lord, she needed no more guard
Than the innocence that sat, dove-like, in her eyes,
That shaped the folding of her delicate hands,
And timed the movement of her gentle feet.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You spoke to her?

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: I dared not; some strange shame
Put weights upon my tongue. I only watched her,
And sometimes heard her sing. That was enough.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Poets are easy satisfied. Well—you watched?

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: And then I found that I was not alone
Upon my nightly post: there were two more;
One staid outside, like me, and one went in.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: True to the letter! I was the outsider,
The third, and luckiest, was Bertuccio!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: The hump-backed hypocrite!

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: The owl that screeched
Still loudest against women!

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: But, is't certain
That 'twas Bertuccio?

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: I can swear to that!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: And I!

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: How do you know him?

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: By his hump—
His gait—who could mistake that crab-like walk?
I could have knocked my head against the wall
To think I had been fool enough to trust
A woman's looks for once:—Dell' Aquila,
I know, holds other faith about the sex.

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: I would stake life upon her purity;
Yet, 'tis past doubt Bertuccio is the man,
The ugly gaoler of this prisoned bird.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Why that's enough to make it a mere duty
To break her prison-house, and shift her keeping
To fitter hands—say mine. I'm lord of the town,
None else has right of prison here but I.

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: What would you do?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: First see if she bears out
Your picture, Serafino—if she do,
Be sure I will not wait outside to mark
Her shadow. Shadows may suit poets—I
Want substance.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: She's meat for Bertuccio's master,
Not for Bertuccio.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: When shall it be?
To-morrow.
I'm a free man! Meet me at midnight, here.

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: You would not harm her? Only see her face,
You will not have the heart to do her wrong.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What call you "wrong?" To save so choice a creature,
From such a guardian as Bertuccio?
He would have prompted me to play the robber
Of Malatesta's pearl;—let him guard his own!

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: If he resists, we'll knock him o'er the sconce:
Let me have that part of the business.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Nay, I'd not have the rascal harmed;—he's bitter,
But shrewdly witty, and he makes me laugh—
No, spare me my buffoon: who does him harm,
Shall answer it to me.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: 'Twere a rare plot to make the knave believe
Our scheme still held against old Malatesta—
That his Ginevra was the game we followed.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: So give him rendezvous a mile away;
And, while he waits our coming, to break open
The mew where he keeps close his tercel gentle.

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: (aside to MANFREDI) Ne'er trust a poet. What if he betrayed us?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: He's truth itself; and where he gives his faith,
'Tis better than a bond of your Lorenzo's.

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: Swear him to secrecy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: (to DELL' AQUILA) Your hand upon it.
You'll not spoil sport, by breaking to Bertuccio
What we intend?

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: But think, oh, think, my lord,
What if this were no mistress—as—if looks
Have privilege to reveal the soul—she is none?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Mistress or maid, man, I will not be baulked;
'Tis for her good; I know the sex—she pines
In her captivity;—I'll find a cage
More fitting such a bird as you've described—
Your hand on't not a whisper to Bertuccio!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: You force me! There's my hand! I will not speak
A word to him!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: (taking his hand) That's like a trusty liegeman
Of blind Lord Cupid! Hark—a word with you!

div.stage: (MANFREDI and LORDS talk apart, C.)

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: I'll save her from this wrong, or lose myself.
What tie there is betwixt these two I know not.
How one so fair and seeming gentle 's linked
With one so foul and bitter—a buffoon,
Who makes even his vile office viler still,
By prompting to the evil that he mocks!
But I will 'gage my life that she is pure,
And still shall be so, if my aid avail!

div.stage: (MANFREDI and LORDS separate)

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Once more, my lord—you'll not be stayed from this
That you propose?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Unconscionable bard!
What—when you've set my mouth a watering
You'd have me put the dainty morsel from me!
Go, feed on sighs and shadows—such thin stuff
Is the best diet for you singing birds;
We eagles must have flesh!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: (to ALL) Good night, my lords!
(aside) Keep to your carrion, kites! She's not for you.

div.stage: Exit AQUILA.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But how to get sight of Bertuccio's jewel?—
I'd see, before I snatch!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Trust me for that!
I am no poet: When I found the damsel
Admitted such a gallant as Bertuccio,
I thought it time to press my suit—and so
Accosted her on her way from San Costanza

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: She listened?

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Long enough—the little fool,—
To learn my meaning—then she flushed, and fled;
I followed—when, as the foul fiend would have it,
Ginevra Malatesta coming by
From vespers with her train sheltered the pigeon,
And spoiled my chase.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You did not give it up?

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: I changed my plan: the mistress being coy,
I spread my net to catch the maid—oh, lord—
The veriest Gorgon! You might swear none e'er
Had given her chase before—no coyness there;
A small expense of oaths and coin sufficed
To make her think herself a misprized Venus,
And me the most discriminating wooer,
In all Faenza. 'Twill not need much art
For me to win an entrance to the house,
And when I'm in, it shall go hard, my lord,
But I find means to get you access too.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: About it straight; at dusk to-morrow night
Be here, armed, masked and cloaked.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: While poor Bertuccio
Awaits our coming near San Stefano!
A stone's throw from the casa Malatesta.

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: He's here!

div.stage: Enter BERTUCCIO, L.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Not yet a-bed!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Since when were the fiend's eggs so hard to hatch?
I left a pleasant little germ of sin
Some half-an-hour since: it should be full grown
By this time—Is it?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Winged, and hoofed, and tailed.
If proud Ginevra Malatesta sleep
To-morrow night beneath old Guido's roof,
Then call me a snow-water-blooded shaveling.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Ha! 'Tis resolved then?

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: We have pledged our faith
To carry off the fairest in Faenza

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: Before the stroke of midnight.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: 'Twas my plan
To gather one by one to the place of action;
Lest, going in a troop, we might awake
Suspicion, and put Guido on his guard.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: A wise precaution, although it was yours.
I wronged you, gentlemen; I thought you shrunk
Even from sin, when there was danger in't.
It seems there are deeds black enough to make
Even Torelli brave, Ascolti prompt,
And Ordelaffi witty. But the place?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Beside San Stefano.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: The hour of meeting?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Half an hour after vespers. There await us.
And now, good rest, my lords; the night wanes fast,
My duchess will be weary.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: (going) Sir, good night!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Sleep well, Torelli. Dream of charging home
In the van of some fierce fight.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: My common dream.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: 'Tis natural—dreams go by contraries!
And you, Ascolti, dream of telling truth;
And, Ordelaffi, that you have grown wise;

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: And, you, that your back's straight, your legs a match,

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: And your tongue tipped with honey.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: Come, my lords,
Leave him to spit his venom at the moon,
As they say toads do!

div.stage: Exeunt, R.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Take my curse among you—
Fair, false, big, brainless, outside shows of men;
For once your gibes and jeers fall pointless from me!
My great revenge is nigh, and drowns all sense.
I am straight, and fair, and well-shaped as yourselves;
Vengeance swells out my veins, and lifts my head,
And makes me terrible!—Come, sweet to-morrow,
And put my enemy's heart into my hand
That I may gnaw it!

div.stage: SCENE FIRST.—A Room in the House of Bertuccio, hung with tapestry; a coloured statue of the Madonna in a recess, with a small lamp burning before it; carved and coloured furniture; a carved cabinet and large carved coffer; in the centre, a window opening on the street, with a balcony; behind the tapestry, a secret door communicating with the street, L. 2 E.; a door, R. 2 E.; a lamp lighted; a lute and flowers; a missal on a stand before the statue; a recess concealed by the tapestry, L. 3 E.
TORELLI and BRIGITTA discovered, C.

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: Hark, there's the quarter! you must hence, fair signor.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: But a few moments more of your sweet presence!

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: Saint Ursula, she knows, 'tis not my will
That drives you hence; but if my master found
That I received a man into the house,
'Twere pity of my place, if not my life.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Your master is a churl, that would condemn
These maiden blooms to wither on the tree.

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: Churl you may call him! why he'd have the house
A prison. If you heard the coil he keeps
Of bolts, and bars, and locks! Lord knows the twitter
I've been in all to-day about the key
I lost this morning—it unlocks the door
Of the turnpike stair that leads down to the street.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: 'Twas lucky I came by just when you dropt it.

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: Dropt!—nay, signor, 'twas whipped off by some cut-purse,
That thought to filch my coin.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: That's a shrewd guess!
He must have flung it from him where I found it,
Not knowing (bowing to her) of what jewel it unlocked
The casket!

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: How can I pay your pains that brought it back?

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: By ever and anon giving me leave
To come and sun myself in your chaste presence.

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: Alas, sweet signor. (coquettishly)

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: (in the same tone) Oh! divine Brigitta!

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: But I must say farewell. Vespers are over;
My mistress will be waiting—she's so fearful.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: As if her unripe beauties were in danger,
While your maturer loveliness can walk
The streets unguarded.

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: Nay—I'm a poor, fond, thing; Lord knows the risk
I run to let you in.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: I warrant now
You've some snug nook where, if your master came,
You could bestow me at a pinch.

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: I know none,
Unless 'twere here, (lifting arras, L. 3 E.) behind the arras, look!
Here's a hole too, whence you could peep to see
When the coast's clear!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: (aside) There's room enough for two.

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: (sternly) Signor!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: (with feigned suspicion) Brigitta!
How if this had served
For hiding others before me?

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: I swear
By the eleven thousand virgins—

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: That's
Too many by ten thousand and ten hundred
And ninety-nine! Vouch but your virgin self,
And I am satisfied!

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: (whimpering) Alack! a-day!
To be suspected after all these years.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Pardon a lover's jealousy—this kiss
Shall wipe away the memory of my wrong.
(aside) What will not loyalty drive a man to?
(kisses her) There!

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: (aside) He has the sweetest lips!—And now begone
Sweet signor, if you love me.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: If, Brigitta!
Banish me then to outer darkness straight!
Farewell, my full-blown rose—let others prize
The opening bud—the ripe, rich flower for me!

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: Oh, the saints, how he talks! This way, sweet signor, (taking a key from her girdle)
The secret door—the key you found and brought me
Unlocks it. (unlocking secret door, L. 2 E.)

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: (taking another from his girdle, aside) Else, why did I filch it from you—
And have this, it's twin brother, forged to-day!

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: (getting the lamp) I'll light you out, and lock the door behind you—
"Safe bind, safe find."

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Good night, sweet piece of woman,
I leave my heart in pledge. (aside) Now for the Duke.

div.stage: (BRIGITTA holds open the door and lights him down—then locks the door)

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: He's gone—bless his sweet face! To think what risks
Men will run that are lovers—and indeed
Weak women too! Lord! if my master knew.
'Tis lucky San Costanza is hard by,—
I should be fearful else. Faenza's full
Of gallants—and who knows what might befall
A poor young woman like myself, with nought
Except her innocence to be her safeguard!

div.stage: Exit BRIGITTA, R. 2 E.
(as soon as she has closed the door, the secret door, L. opens, and TORELLI re-appears)

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: This way, my lord—the dragon has departed.

div.stage: Enter MANFREDI from the secret door, L. 2 E.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis time—I was aweary of my watch!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: You were alone, at least. Think of my lot,
That had to make love to a tough old spinster!
I would we had changed parts, why, good, my lord,
I had to kiss her! Faugh! When shall I get
The garlic from my beard? —But here's the cage
That holds our bird! We must ensconce ourselves,
For they'll be here anon—vespers were over
Before we entered!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thanks to your device
Of the forged key!—yet that was scarcely needed;
I've climbed more break-neck balconies than that (pointing to window)
Without a silken ladder! (looking about) So—a lute—
A missal—flowers! more tokens of a maid
Than of a mistress—Well, so much the better;
I long to see the girl! Is she as fair
As Serafino painted?

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Faith, my lord,
She's fair enough to justify more sonnets
Than e'er fat Petrarch pumped out for his Laura.
She is a paragon of blushing girlhood,
Full of temptation to the finger-tips.
I marvel at myself, that e'er I yielded
This amorous enterprise, even to you—
But that my loyalty outbears my love.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I will requite your loyalty—fear not;
But where shall we bestow ourselves?

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: (lifting the arras from the recess) In here;
The old crone showed it me but now,—there's cover
And peeping-place sufficient. Hark! they come!
Stand close, my lord.

div.stage: They retire behind the arras.
Enter FIORDELISA and BRIGITTA, R. 2 E.

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: And he was there to-night?

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Oh yes! He offered me the holy water
As I passed in. I trembled so, Brigitta,
When our hands met, I fear he must have marked it,
But that he seemed almost as trembling, too,
As I was.

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: He! a brazen popinjay,
I'll warrant me, for all his downcast looks!
I wonder how my master would endure
To hear of such audacious goings on!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: That makes me sad. My father is so kind,
I cannot bear to have a secret from him.
Sometimes I feel as I would tell him all;
But then, I think, perhaps he would forbid me
From going out to church;—and, 'tis so dull
To be shut up here all the long bright day;
From morn till dark, to mark the busy stir
Under the window, and the happy voices
Of holiday-makers, that go out and in
Just as they please. Look at the birds, Brigitta!
Their wings are free, yet no harm comes to them;
I'm sure they're innocent! And then to hear
Sometimes the trumpets, as the knights ride by,
And tramp of men-at-arms—(a lute sounds without)—sometimes a lute.
Hark! 'tis his lute! I know the air—how sweet!
My good Brigitta, would there be much harm
If I touched mine—only a little touch,
To tell him I am listening?

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: Holy saints,
Was e'er such boldness! I must have your lute
Locked up. These girls! these girls!—Bar them from Court,
And they'll find matter in church; keep them from speech,
And they'll make cat-gut do the work of tongue!
Better be charged to keep a cat from cream,
Than a girl from gallants!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Nay but, good Brigitta,
This gentleman is none.

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: How do you know?

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: He never speaks to me—scarce looks—or if
He do, it is but to withdraw his gaze
As hastily as I do mine. I've seen him
Blush when our eyes met; not like yon rude man,
Who pressed upon me with such words and looks,
As made me red and hot, you know the time—
When that kind lady, Countess Malatesta,
Scarce saved me from his boldness.

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.l: Tilly-vally.
There are more ways of bird-catching than one;
He's the best fowler, who least scares his quarry.
But I must go and see the supper toward.
Your father will be here anon!

div.stage: Exit BRIGITTA, R.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Dear father!
Would he were here, that I might rest my head
Upon his breast, and have his arms about me;
For then I feel there's something I may love,
And not be chidden for it. (lute sounds) Hark! again—
If I durst answer!
How sad he must be out there in the dark,
Not knowing if I mark his music.
(takes her lute, then puts it away) No!
My father would be angry—sad enough
To have one joy I may not share with him;
Yet there can be no harm in listening—
I thought to-night he would have spoken to me,
But then Brigitta came and he fell back!
I'm glad he did not speak—and yet I'm sorry—
I should so like to hear his voice—just once—
He comes in my dreams, now—but he never speaks—
I'm sure 'tis soft and sweet! (listening) His lute is hushed.
What, if I touched mine, now that he is gone?
I must not look out of the casement!—Yes—
I'm sure he's gone! (takes her lute, and strikes a chord, L.)

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: (aside, lifting the arras) She is worth ten Ginevras!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: (holding him back) Not yet!—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Unhand me—I will speak to her!

div.stage: BERTUCCIO appears at the door, R. 2 E.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: My Lord! It is Bertuccio! In—quick!

div.stage: (BERTUCCIO stands for a moment fondly contemplating FIORDELISA—his dress is sober and his manner composed. He steps quietly forward)

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: My own!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: (turning suddenly, and flinging herself into his arms with a cry of joy) My father!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (embracing her tenderly) Closer, closer yet!
Let me feel those soft arms about my neck,
This dear cheek on my heart! No—do not stir—
It does me so much good! I am so happy—
These minutes are worth years!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: My own dear father!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Let me look at thee, darling—why, thou growest
More and more beautiful! Thou'rt happy here?
Hast all that thou desirest—thy lute—thy flowers?
She loves her poor old father?—Blessings on thee—
I know thou dost—but tell me so.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: I love you—
I love you very much! I am so happy
When you are with me—Why do you come so late,
And go so soon? Why not stay always here?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Why not! why not! Oh, if I could! To live
Where there's no mocking, and no being mocked—
No laughter, but what's innocent; no mirth
That leaves an after-bitterness like gall.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Now, you are sad! There's that black ugly cloud
Upon your brow—you promised, the last time,
It never should come when we were together.
You know when you're sad, I'm sad too.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: My bird!
I'm selfish even with thee—let dark thoughts come,
That thy sweet voice may chase them, as they say
The blessèd church-bells drive the demons off.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: If I but knew the reason of your sadness,
Then I might comfort you; but I know nothing—
Not even your name.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I'd have no name for thee,
But, "father."

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: In the convent, at Cesena,
Where I was rear'd, they used to call me orphan.
I thought I had no father, till you came,
And then they needed not to say I had one;
My own heart told me that.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I often think
I had done well to have left thee there, in the peace
Of that still cloister. But it was too hard—
My empty heart so hungered for my child!—
For those dear eyes that look no scorn for me—
That voice that speaks respect and tenderness,
Even for me!—My dove—my lily-flower—
My only stay in life!—Oh, God! I thank thee
That thou hast left me this at least! (he weeps)

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Dear father!
You're crying now—you must not cry—you must not—
I cannot bear to see you cry.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Let be!—
'Twere better than to see me laugh.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: But wherefore?
You say you are so happy here—and yet
You never come but to weep bitter tears.
And I can but weep too—not knowing why.
Why are you sad? Oh, tell me—tell me all!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I cannot. In this house I am thy father:
Out of it, what I am boots not to say;
Hated, perhaps—or envied—feared, I hope,
By many—scorned by more—and loved by none.
In this one innocent corner of the world
I would but be to thee a father—something
August, and sacred!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: And you are so, father.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I love thee with a love strong as the hate
I bear for all but thee. Come, sit beside me,
With thy pure hand in mine—and tell me still,
"I love you," and "I love you"—only that.
Smile on me—so!—thy smile is passing sweet!
Thy mother used to smile so once—oh, God!
I cannot bear it. Do not smile—it wakes
Memories that tear my heart-strings. Do not look
So like thy mother, or I shall go mad!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Oh, tell me of my mother!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: No, no, no!
Yes.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: She's dead?

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: You were with her when she died?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: No! leave the dead alone—talk of thyself.—
Thy life here—Thou heed'st well my caution, girl—
Not to go out by day, nor show thyself
There, at the casement.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Yes: some day, I hope,
You will take me with you, but to see the town—
'Tis so hard to be shut up here, alone—

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Thou hast not stirred abroad? (suspiciously and eagerly)

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Only to vespers—
You said I might do that with good Brigitta—
I never go forth, or come in alone.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: That's well. I grieve that thou should'st live so close.
But if thou knew'st what poison's in the air—
What evil walks the streets—How innocence
Is a temptation—beauty but a bait
For desperate desires:—no man, I hope,
Has spoken to thee?

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Only one.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (fiercely) Ha! who?

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: I know not—'twas against my will.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (eagerly) You gave
No answer?

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: No—I fled

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (in the same tone) He followed you?

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: A gracious lady gave me kind protection,
And bade her train guard me safe home—Oh, father,
If you had seen how good she was—how gently
She soothed my fears—for I was sore afraid—
I'm sure you'd love her.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Did you learn her name!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: I asked it, first, to set it in my prayers—
And then, that you might pray for her.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Her name?—(aside) I pray! (contemptuously)

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: The Countess Malatesta.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (aside) Count Malatesta's wife protect my child!
You have not seen her since?

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: No; though she urged me
So hard to come to her; and asked my name;
And who my parents were; and where I lived.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: You did not tell her?

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Who my parents were?
How could I, when I must not know myself?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Patience, my darling; trust thy father's love,
That there is reason for this mystery!
The time may come when we may live in peace,
And walk together free, under free heaven;
But that cannot be here—nor now!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Oh, when—
When shall that time arrive?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (bitterly) When what I live for
Has been achieved!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: (timidly) What you live for?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (with sudden ferocity) Revenge!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: (averting her eyes with horror) Oh, do not look so, father!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Listen, girl,—
You asked me of your mother;—it is time
You should know why all questioning of her
Racks me to madness. Look upon me, child;
Misshapen, as I am, there once was one,
Who, seeing me despised, mocked, lonely, poor—
Loved me—I think most for my misery:
Thy mother, like thee—just so pure—so sweet.
I was a public notary in Ceséna:
Our life was humble but so happy: thou
Wert in thy cradle then, and many a night
Thy mother and I sate hand in hand together,
Watching thine innocent smiles, and building up
Long plans of joy to come! (his voice falters—he turns away)

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Alas! she died!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Died! There are deaths 'tis comfort to look back on:
Her's was not such a death. A devil came
Across our quiet life, and marked her beauty,
And lusted for her; and when she scorned his offers,
Because he was a noble—great and strong,
He bore her from my side—by force—and after
I never saw her more: they brought me news
That she was dead!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Ah me!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: And I was mad,
For years and years, and when my wits came back,—
If e'er they came, they brought one haunting purpose,
That since has shaped my life—to have revenge!
Revenge upon her wronger and his order;
Revenge in kind; to quit him—wife for wife!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Father, 'tis not for me to question with you:
But think?—revenge belongeth not to man,
It is God's attribute—usurp it not!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Preach abstinence to him that dies of hunger—
Tell the poor wretch who perishes of thirst,
There's danger in the cup his fingers clutch;
But bid me not forswear revenge. No word!
Thou know'st, now, why I mew thee up so close;
Keep thee out of the streets; shut thee from eyes
And tongues of lawless men—for in these days
All men are lawless.—'Tis because I fear
To lose thee, as I lost thy mother.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Father,
I'll pray for her.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Do—and for me; good night!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Oh, not so soon—with all these sad dark thoughts,
These bitter memories. You need my love:
I'll touch my lute for you, and sing to it.
Music, you know, chases all evil angels.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I must go: 'tis grave business calls me hence—
(aside) 'Tis time that I was at my post—My own,
Sleep in thine innocence. Good night! good night!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: But let me see you to the outer door.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Not a step further, then. God guard this place,
That here my flower may grow, safe from the blight
Of look, or word impure, a holy thing
Consecrate to thy service, and my love!

div.stage: Exit BERTUCCIO and FIORDELISA, R.
Enter from behind the arras, MANFREDI and TORELLI.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: His daughter! That so fair a branch should spring
From such a gnarled and misshapen stock!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: But did you mark how he raved of revenge
Upon our order?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: By the mass! I think
That Guido Malatesta is the man
That played him the shrewd trick he told the girl of.
'Twas at Ceséna, marked you—the time fits—
That's why he hounds me on after the countess.
What! Must I be the tool of his revenge?
I'll teach the scurril slave to strike at nobles!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Hark! what's that? (listening)

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis outside the window!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: (listening) By Bacchus, some one climbs the balcony!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: A gallant?

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: In, sir; see the play played out.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But I'll not be forestalled!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Yes, We've time enough.

div.stage: (they retire to the recess)
Enter AQUILA from the balcony.

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Pardon, sweet saint, if I profane thy shrine,
I watched Bertuccio forth—he passed me close—
I feared he would have seen me. I have sworn
Not to betray their foul design to him.
And to warn her, this means alone is left me.
Hark! 'tis her gracious step—she comes this way.

div.stage: Enter FIORDELISA, she kneels before the statue of the Madonna.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Comfort of the afflicted—comfort him!
Turn his revengeful purpose to sumbission,
And grant that I may grow to take the place
My mother has left empty in his heart!
He's gone! And I had not the heart to speak
Of the young gentleman who follows me.
He asked if any spoke to me—I told
The truth—he never spoke to me.(turning round and seeing AQUILA)
Who's there!
Brigitta! help!—

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Silence! but have no fear—
I am not here to harm you—do not tremble.
I would die, lady, rather than offend you.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Oh, sir! how came you here?

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: I knew no way
But by the balcony. Desperate occasions
Dispense with ceremony. My respect
Is absolute. Fear not: I am not here
To say, "I love you," nor to tell you how
For months your face has been my beacon star.
My passion never would have found a tongue,
It is too reverent; but your safety, lady,
I can be bold for that.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: My safety!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Threatened
With desperate danger. Think you, one so fair
Could even pray in safety in Faenza?
You have been seen: your beauty hath been buzzed
In the Court's amorous ear: there is a project
To scale your balcony to-night.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Oh, father!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: He cannot save you—what were his sole strength
Against the bravos that the duke commands,
For any deed of ill. My arm and sword
Are stronger than your father's—and are your's
As absolutely. And yet what were these?
I could die for you—but I could not save you.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Have you no friends—protectors
To whom you might betake yourself?

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Alas!
I am a stranger here.

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Think—have you none?

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Ha!—if the Countess Malatesta—

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: You know her?

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: She once rescued me from insult
Of a rude man; and promised help whene'er
I chose to seek it.

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: She is good, and pure,
And powerful moreover. That's the chief.
Go to her straight—you have no time to lose.
Midnight is fixed for their foul enterprise.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: But how to find the house? And then the streets
Are dark and dangerous. I've but our servant,
Brigitta—

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Not a word to her! She's false.
Can you trust me? I'll lead you to the countess.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: (aside) Were this a stratagem!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: I see you doubt me.
I know you have good cause to doubt all men.
Oh, could I bare my heart, and shew you there
Your image set amongst its holiest thoughts,
Beside my mother's well-remembered face—
Could truth speak with the tongue, look from the eyes,
You would not doubt me! What can oaths avail?
He who could cheat you, would not fear to cheat
God, and his saints! Lady, it is the truth
That I have spoken! May heaven give you faith
To trust in me; but if not, I will stay,
And die in your defence.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Sir, I will trust you!
And heaven so deal with you, as you with me!—
Go with me to the Countess Malatesta—
I'll seek the shelter of her roof to-night.
To-morrow must bring counsel for the future.

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Oh! bless you for this trust! Come—quick—but softly—
Put on your veil—fear not—I am your guard,
Your slave, your sentinel. I crave no guerdon—
Not even a look! Enough for me to save you.

div.stage: Exit FIORDELISA and DELL'AQUILA.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: (breaking out from behind the arras, TORELLI following him) Why did you hold me back? Our project's marred.
This moonstruck poet bears away the prize,
And I am fooled.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Nay; trust my cooler brain.
I'll follow them to Malatesta's. Sure
He'll give her shelter?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: In his lady's absence?

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Even so. The old ruffian can be courteous
When there's a pretty face in question!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Let him!
I'll break his house, or any man's that dares
Set his locks in the way of my good pleasure!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Why not? 'Twill give a double pungency
To our revenge upon Bertuccio.
We only looked to keep the foul-mouthed knave
Out of the way, while we bore off his pearl;
But now we'll use him for the robbery.
He shall see us scale Malatesta's windows;
But she whom we bear thence, muffled and gagged,
Shall be the hunch-backed scoffer's pretty daughter!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: A rare revenge! and so this brain-sick poet
And my curst jester may console each other.
Watch them to Malatesta's! I'll to our friends,
And find Bertuccio by San Stefano!

div.stage: Exit by secret door, L. 2 E.
SCENE SECOND.—A Street near the Church of San Stefano; stage dark.
Enter BERTUCCIO, L., cloaked and masked.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: The hour has struck—they will be here anon—
Trust them to keep tryst for a villainous deed—
I had need to whet the memory of my wrong,
Or my girl's angel face, and innocent tongue
Had shaken even my steadfastness of purpose!
And Malatesta's wife has done her kindness—
I would she had not! But what's such slight service
To my huge Wrong? Let me but think of that!
I grow too human near my child. I lack
The sharp sting of court scorn to spur the sides
Of my intent! With her I'm free to weep—
With them, I still must laugh—still be their ape
To mop, and mow, and wake their shallow mirth.—
True—I can sometimes bite—as monkeys do.
They'll make mirth of that too! Oh, courtly sirs!
Sweet-spoken, stalwart gallants! if you knew
The hate that rankles underneath my motley!
The scorn that barbs my wit—the bitterness
That grins behind my laughter—you would start,
And shudder o'er your cups, and cross yourselves
As if the devil were in your company!
Once my revenge achieved, I'll spurn my chain—
Fool it no more—but give what's left of life
To thought of her I've lost, and love of her
That yet is left me.

div.stage: Enter MANFREDI, ASCOLTI, and ORDELAFFI, masked and cloaked.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Hist! Bertuccio!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Here, gossip Galeotto—you are punctual—
Ascolti, too, grave Signor Florentine,
We'll show you how the gallants of Faenza
Treat greybeards who aspire to handsome wives.
Remember, your beard's grizzled and beware—

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: I will stand warned. You have the ladders here?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: The lackeys wait in charge of them hard by.
But where's Torelli?—we shall want his help.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: Pshaw! our three swords are plenty.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Cry you mercy!
'Tis not Torelli's sword we want.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: His marvellous quick scent of danger, man.
Stick to his skirts—I'll answer for't, you're safe.
Perhaps he smelt some risk of buffets here,
And so has ta'en him home to bed.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Away
Towards Malatesta's house—'twas there he promised
To meet us. Sirrah fool, be it thy post
To hold the ladder while we mount—and see
Thou play'st us no jade's trick, or 'ware the whip!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Fear not, magnanimous gossip—do your work
With as good will as I do mine. The countess
Sleeps in the chamber of the balcony,
Which rounds the angle of the southern front:
I came but now by the palace—all was quiet.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Set on then, cautiously—use not your swords,
Unless on strong compulsion: blood tells tales—
And I want no more feuds upon my hands.

div.stage: Exeunt, R.

SCENE THIRD.—Exterior of the Palace of Malatesta, with Street. The flat exhibits the corner of two streets. The Palace of Malatesta is on a set piece, L. U. E.—A window on the first floor, with a balcony, practicable.—Night.

Enter FIORDELISA and DELL'AQUILA, followed by TORELLI at a distance. Through the Scene between FIORDELISA, DELL'AQUILLA, and MALATESTA, TORELLI watches and listens behind a projecting piece of masonry.

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Be of good cheer—this is the house—I'll knock
And summon forth the count. (knocks)

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Oh, sir! what thanks
Can e'er repay this kindness?

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: But remember,
Who 'twas that did it: I am thanked enough.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: I'll pray for you, after my father—hark!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: They come!

div.stage: Enter a SERVANT from house.

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Two strangers who crave instant speech
Of the Count Malatesta.

div.stage: Exit SERVANT.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: And should I see your father?

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Then you know him!
And his business—occupations? (he bows)
(sadly) 'Tis more than I do, sir, that am his child.
I do not even know his name.

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: What he
Keeps secret from you 'tis not mine to tell;
'Twere well you should not question him too closely:
He shall learn you are safe.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: And tell him, too,
That 'twas you saved me, sir—Promise me that.

div.stage: Enter MALATESTA, L.

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: Who is it would have speech of Malatesta?

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: You know me, count?

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: Dell' Aquila, well met!
But your companion? (aside) Ha! a petticoat!
So ho, my poet!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Pardon, if I pray
This lady's name may rest a secret, count;
She is in grievous danger, one from which
Your house can shelter her. She owes already
Your countess much, for good help given at need,
So craves to increase the debt.

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: My house is hers,
But she should know my countess is not here.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Not here!

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: But if she dare trust my grey hairs
She shall have shelter.

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Nay, she cannot choose.

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: I'll give her my wife's chamber, if she will;
Her woman to attend her.

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: All she needs
Is your roof's shelter for the night; to-morrow
Must see her otherwise bestowed.

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: Go in,
Fair lady; my poor house, with all that's in it
Is at your service;—had my wife been here,
You had had gentler tendance; as it is
I'll lead you to her chamber, and there leave you.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: (aside) Now to the hunters: I've marked down the deer.

div.stage: Exit TORELLI, L. U. E.

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: (to AQUILA) You will not stay and crush a cup with me?

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: No—not to-night. (to FIORDELISA) Did you not well to trust me?
Farewell; think of me in your prayers!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: I cannot
Choose but do that, sir;—(aside) Oh, the thought of him
Will come, henceforth, betwixt my prayers and heaven!

div.stage: Exit MALATESTA, L., leading in FIORDELISA.

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: His child!—Since when did grapes grow upon thistles?
And yet I'm glad to know the tie that binds
The two together such a holy one!
Sweet angel—sister angels guard thy sleep!
Now, to seek out Bertuccio, and tell him
The danger she has 'scaped and thank the saints
That made me her preserver.

div.stage: Exit DELL'AQUILA, R.
Enter cautiously, L. U. E,. BERTUCCIO, MANFREDI, ASCOLTI, ORDELAFFI, and TORELLI, with SERVANTS carrying ladders.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Softly, you knaves! with velvet tread, like tigers—

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Say rather, "cats."

div.stage: (a light appears from the window, L. 2 E.)

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Which is the balcony?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (pointing) That! I have noted in this summer weather
The window's left unbarred. Ha, there's a light!

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: If she were stirring?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: What, an' if she were?
A sudden spring—a cloak flung o'er her head:
If she have time to scream, you are but bunglers.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My cloak will serve. (takes it off)

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: If she alarm the house
It might go hard with us.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Oh, cats that long
For fish, yet fear to wet your feet! I'll shame you.
Let me mount first: give me your cloak, Galeotto!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: By your leave, fool, I'll net my own bird. Back!
Hold thou the ladder—that is lacqueys' work,
And fits thee best. Ascolti and Torelli,
Guard the approaches! I and Ordelaffi
Will be enough to mount, and snare the game.

div.stage: (the light is extinguished; the SERVANTS set a ladder to the balcony)

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (holds it) All's dark now—Up!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Why, rogue, how thy hand shakes:
Is't fear?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: 'Tis inward laughter, Galeotto.
To think how blank Guido will look to-morrow
To find the nest cold, and his mate borne off.

div.stage: (MANFREDI mounts the ladder, followed by ORDELAFFI—they enter the balcony)

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (eagerly listening) Ha! they are in by this time! Cautious fools!
I had done 't myself in half the space! So, Guido,
You love your young wife well, they say: that's brave.

div.stage: (MANFREDI and ORDELAFFI appear on the balcony, bearing FIORDELISA in their arms, muffled in MANFREDI's cloak—she struggles, but cannot scream—ORDELAFFI descends first—MANFREDI hands FIORDELISA to him they come down the ladder)

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: 'Tis done!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Away all—to my garden house,
There to bestow our prize!

div.stage: Exeunt MANFREDI and ORDELAFFI, L. U. E. the SERVANTS carry off the ladder.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Now, Malatesta, (shaking his fist at the house)
Learn what it is to wake, and find her gone,
That was the joy and pride of your dim eyes—
The comfort of your age! I welcome you
To the blank hearth—the hunger of the soul—
The long dark days, and miserable nights!
These you gave me—I give them back to you!
I, the despised, deformed, dishonoured jester,
Have reached up to your crown, and pulled it down,
And flung it in the mire, as you flung mine!
Now, murdered innocent, thou art avenged!
But I have private wrongs, too, to repay:
This proud Manfredi—he you spat upon,
He you spurned such a day, set in the stocks,
Whipped—he is even with your mightiness!
Here is Francesca's ring; and here the letter,
To tell her that her vengeance, too, is ripe.
The blow shall come from her; but mine's the hand
That guides the dagger's point straight to his heart!
I cannot sleep! I'll walk the night away:
It is no night for me—my day has come!

div.stage: Exit, R.

SCENE.—A Room in the Garden-house of Galeotto Manfredi, decorated with arabesques in the style of the earlier Renaissance. Folding doors at the back, communicating with an inner chamber; side entrances, R. and L., covered by curtains; a table, and chairs of the curule form.
Enter FIORDELISA from R.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: (pressing her hands to her temples) Where am I? What has happened? Let me think:
Those men!—That blinding veil!—The fresh night air,
That struck upon my face. Then a wild struggle,
In strong and mastering arms! Then a long blank—
I must have fainted—when I woke, I lay
On a rich couch in that room. Has he brought me
Into the very danger that he said
He came to take me from? Oh, cruel! No,
Falsehood could ne'er have found such words, such looks.
Father! Oh, when he comes and finds me gone!—
I must go hence! (looking round) That door!—(she runs to side entrance, L.)
'Tis locked! (shaking door) Help! help!
How dare they draw their bolts on me? My father
Shall punish them for this! I will go forth!

l.stage: (shakes door again the door opens from without)

sp.l: At last! Whoe'er you are, sir, help me hence!

div.stage: Enter MANFREDI, L

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Take me back to my father! He will bless you!
Reward you!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Nay, your own lips must do that.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Oh, they shall bless you too, sir—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: To be blessed
With that sweet mouth were well—yet scarce enough.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Oh, sir, we waste time. Set what price you will
On the great service, I am sure my father
Will pay you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: If we're to discuss your ransom
'Twere fairest we should do it with closed doors—
The terms can scarce be settled, till you know
Your prison, jailer, in what risk you stand.
First, for your prison—Know you where you are?

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: No—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: In the Duke Manfredi's palace. Next—
Know you your jailer?

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Who?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Manfredi's self.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: (wringing her hands) Woe's me!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What? Is the news so terrible?

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: I've heard Brigitta and my father too,
Speak of the Duke Manfredi.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: (aside) Here's a chance
To hear a genuine judgment of myself!
(to her) They said—

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: That he was cruel, bold, unsated
In thirst for evil pleasures:—it was odds
Whether more feared, or hated, in Faenza.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: (aside) Trust the crowd's garlic cheers, and greasy caps!
The knaves shall know me worse ere they have done.
I thank you, pretty one—I am the Duke!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Then heaven have mercy on me!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: If report
Speak truth, your prayer were idle!—but report
Is a sad liar. Do I look the ogre
They painted to you? Nay, my fluttered dove,
Smooth but those ruffled feathers—look about you!
Is this so grim a dungeon?—Was your couch
Last nigh so hard—your 'tendance so ungentle?
I am your prisoner, fairest—not you mine.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Then let me go.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Not till you know, at least,
What you will lose by going. All Faenza
Is mine—and she I favour may command
Whate'er Faenza holds of wealth or pleasure,
I'll pour them at her feet—and after, fling
Myself there too, to woo a gracious word!
What's life, ungraced by love?—a dismal sky
Without sun, moon, or starlight!—'Tis a cup
Drained of the wine that reddened in its gold!—
A lute shorn of its strings—a table stripped
Of all its festal meats!—mere life in death!
A jewel like thy beauty is not meet
To be shut in a chest;—it should be set
To shine in princely robes—to grace a crown.
I would set thee in mine! (approaching her)

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Stand back, my lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Why, little fool, I would not harm a hair
On thy fair head. Think what thy life has been!
How dull, and dark, and dreary!—It shall be
As bright, and glad, and sunny, as the prime
Of summer flowers!—Only repel not joy
Because it comes borne in the hand of Love!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Oh, you profane that name! Is Love the friend
Of night, and violence, and robbery?
Let me go hence, I say—I have a father
Who'll make you terribly abye this wrong,
Lord as you are!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Your father! By the mass,
She makes me laugh! Your father, girl! Bertuccio!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: That I should learn my father's name from him!
Yes, Duke, my father!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Why, he is my slave—
A thing that crouches to me like my hound,
To beg for food, or deprecate the lash—
My butt—my whipping-block—my fool in motley.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: It is not true. This is a lie, like all
That you have said. Let me go forth, I say.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You're in my palace. Here are none but those
To whom my will is law; your calls for help
Will only bring more force—if I could stoop
To use force with a lady—

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Then you have
Some manhood in you. Look, sir, at us two—
You are a duke, you say—your power but bounded
By your own will. I am a poor weak girl,
E'en weaker than I knew, if what you say
Touching my father, be the truth. What honour
Is to be won on me? Yet, won it may be,
By yielding to my prayers, to be set free—
To be sent home. Oh, let me but go hence,
As I came hither; I will speak to none
Of this night's outrage—even to my father.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Ask anything but this.

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Nothing but this!
You have a wife, my lord, what if she knew?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: The more need to take care you tell her not!
Come, little one, give up these swelling looks,
Though they become you mightily. (approaching her)

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Stand off! (he pursues her, she flies) Help! help!
(running to the C. door) A door! ha! (she forces it open, rushes in, and closes it violently).

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: (locking it outside) Deeper in the toils!
(laughs) The lamb seeks shelter in the wolf's own den.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: (at L. door, outside) My lord!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: (unlocks the door) Torelli's voice! how now, Torelli?

div.stage: Enter TORELLI, L.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: My lord, the duchess is returned.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Why, man,
Thy news is stale; the duchess hath been here
These five hours; she arrived, post haste, ere-sunrise.
She must have ridden in the dark. 'Twas that
Prevented me from making earlier matins
Before my little saint here.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Do you know
What brought the duchess back so suddenly?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Some jealous fancy pricked her, as I judge
From her accost when we encountered first;
And, as I gathered, she suspects contrivance
Betwixt me and the Countess Malatesta.
'Twas a relief, for once, that I could twit her
With groundless fears. I told her Malatesta
Rode yesterday with his lady to Ceséna,
And, for more proof, repeated what he said,
That on my wife's least summons, she'd return;
So she has summoned her, in hopes, no doubt,
To catch me in a lie. Her messenger
Rode to Ceséna, just at daybreak. Soon
We may look for him back, bringing, I hope,
Ginevra Malatesta.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: This is rare.
So falls she off the scent, and leaves you here
To follow up your game with Fiordelisa.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Even so: I excused me from her presence
By work of state, for which to this pavilion
I had summoned you and the Envoy of Florence—
Said work of state, being no less a one
Than to lend me your presence at the banquet
I mean to offer our fair prisoner.
Bid Ordelaffi and Ascolti hither,
And send my men with fruits, and wine, and sweetmeats,—
All that is likeliest to tempt the sense
Of this scared bird.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: How did you find her, sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Beating her pretty wings against the bars;
Still calling for her father. Shrewdly minded
To peck, instead of kissing, silly fledgling!
But I will tame her yet, till she shall come
To perch upon my finger.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Where is she?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: In the inner room, whither she fled but now.
Fear not—I turned the key on her; she's safe.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: I'll send what you command, and warn the rest
That you attend them. Good speed to your wooing.

div.stage: Exit TORELLI, by entrance, L.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Now for my prisoner! By gentle means
To gain her ear. Asmodeus, tip my tongue
With love's persuasion!

div.stage: Exit MANFREDI into inner room, C.
Enter the DUCHESS FRANCESCA, masked, and BERTUCCIO, who has resumed his fool's dress, R.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: (unmasking) Was't not Torelli went hence, even now?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: By the great walk? I think it was. Be sure
He saw us not in the pleached laurel alley.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Then you still bear me out, my husband lies?
That Malatesta's wife has not gone hence?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Trust a fool's eyes before a husband's tongue!
I say again, I was at hand last night
When your lord bore from Malatesta's house
Said Malatesta's wife. I saw the deed.
I heard the order given to bring her hither.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Then 'twas by force, not by the lady's will
She came?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Force? Quotha—force! How many ladies
Have had to bless the "force" that saved their tongue
An awkward "yes." See you not what an answer
"Force" finds for all? It stops a husband's mouth;
Crams its fist down the town's throat; nay; at a pinch
Perks its sufficient self in a wife's face;—
Commend me still to "force." It saves more credits
Then e'er it ruined virtues. After folly,
I hold force the best mask that wit has found
To mock the world with!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: There's weight in that.
This violence would stand her in good stead,
Were she e'er called in question! Then what matter
sp.stage: (BERTUCCIO, who has been moving round the room, stops opposite the centre door)
sp.l: So I be wronged, if 'tis by force, or will.
Would I had certain proof!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Ha! You want proof?
Come here (the DUCHESS approaches him).
Stand where I stand. Now listen—close.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: (listening at door) My husband's voice in passionate entreaty!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Only his voice?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: (starting) An answering voice!—a woman's!
These are your state affairs, my gracious duke!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: If you would have more proof, I'll bring you where
You shall hear his humble tools in last night's business
Discuss the deed—all noble gentlemen
Who'd pluck my hood about my ears if I
Durst hint a doubt of their veracity.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Do so—and if they bear thy story out
I know my part.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: What, tears?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Tears? Death to both.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Take care. His guards are faithful. Can you trust
A hand to do the deed?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I trust my own.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Women turn pale at blood. Your heart may fail you,
When the time comes to strike.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I know a surer weapon.
Daggers for men.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (creeping up to her and whispering) Poison?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: (putting her finger on her lip) Hush!
The Borgia's physician gave it me!
It may be trusted!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (withdrawing, aside) My she leopard's loosed!

div.stage: Exit BERTUCCIO, L.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: (still at the door, C., listening).
Past doubt, a woman's tongue! And now my husband's!
How well I know the soft, smooth, pleading voice—
The voice that drew my young heart to my lips
When, at my father's court, I plighted troth
To him—and he to me! Oh, bitterness!
Now spurned for each new leman of the hour!
Oh, he shall learn how terrible is hate
That grows of love abused. (taking a phial from her bosom) Come, bosom friend,
That hast lain cold, of late, against my heart—
As if to whisper to it" Be thou stone,
When the time calls for me." (looking at the phial) Each drop's a death!
What matter who she be? Enough for me
That she usurps the place which should be mine
In Galeotto's love! Hark! some one comes.

div.stage: (she conceals the phial, and resumes her mask)

Enter TWO CHAMBERLAINS with white wands, L., followed by ATTENDANTS bearing a banquet, and pass into the inner room. After them a PAGE with wine in golden flagon—goblets, fruit, &c., on a salver.—She stops him as he is going through the folding doors.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Hold, sir, set down your charge.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: By your leave, madam:
'Tis for my lord.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Since when was that an answer
To give thy lady? (removes her mask)

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: (aside) 'Tis the Duchess! (respectfully) Pardon,—
I knew you not.
