sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Enough, sir—set it down,
And wait without till I bid thee bear in.

div.stage: Exit PAGE, L., after placing the salver on a table.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What need of further proof? Is't heaven or hell
That sends this apt occasion? Galeotto,
I warned thee in the spring-time of our loves,
This hand could kill as easy as caress;
You laughed, and took it in your ampler palm,
And said that death were pleasant from such white
And taper fingers. Try it now!

div.stage: (she pours some of the contents of the phial into the flagons of wine)
Re-enter BERTUCCIO, L., hastily.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Hide, here, Madonna: here their lordships come!
I met them on the way—so brave and merry—
My gossip Galeotto bids them here.
To feast with him and her!

div.stage: Exit BERTUCCIO, L.
(FRANCESCA starts as if stung—then goes to the door and beckons)
Re-enter PAGE, L.—she signs to him—he bears in the wine.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: (aside) Their doom is sealed!

div.stage: She retires behind curtained entrance, R.
Re-enter BERTUCCIO, with ASCOLTI and ORDELAFFI, L.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: It is your due;—you that go out bat-fowling
Lack wine o' mornings to keep up your hearts.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: Why thou wert there, knave; yet try thou to enter
Into the presence, and they'll whip thee back;
His highness wants no fool to-day!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: That's true
With you two for his company. But tell me,
How will the lady relish o'er her wine,
The cut-throat faces that she saw last night?
Methinks, 'twill mar her appetite.

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: Be sure
She will not look so scared at us,
As thou would'st at the sight of her.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Who—I?
Nay, I but held the ladder;—we, poor knaves,
Must take the leavings of your rogueries,
As of your feasts: but, pr'ythee, Ordelaffi,
How looked she in her night-rail?

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: Would'st believe it?
Methought she had a something of thy favor;
As, if so crook'd a thing could have a daughter,
Thy daughter might have had.

div.stage: (all laugh—BERTUCCIO starts)

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: How now? He winces.
There cannot, sure, be issue of thy loins!
Nature's too merciful: she broke the mould
When she turned thee out!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Nature, sir, proportions
Her witty fools to her dull ones: while she makes
Ascoltis, she must needs produce Bertuccios
To sting their hard hides now and then. But tell me,
Think you Ginevra needed all that force?

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: She struggled stoutly; but a lady's struggles,
I take it, are much like her "no" which often
Must be read, "yes."

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: Let's in, at once, my lords.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I'll marshal you;—who said that cap and bells
Should be shut out?

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: Stand back, Sir Fool, 'twere best;
You may repent your pressing on too far.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I fain would see the lady—'tis not often
That one can carry a beauty off at night,
And make her laugh i' the morning.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: Neither she,
Nor you, I think, are like to breed much mirth
Out of each other.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Say you so? Here goes!

div.stage: (he runs up to the door, a PAGE opens it and motions him back, two CHAMBERLAINS appearing at the open door)
div.l: Why, how now, sirrah?—I'm the fool!

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Stand back!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I!—why I'm free o' the palace—every place
Except the council-chamber, and in that
I sit by proxy!

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: 'Tis the Duke's strict order
You enter not this room. (BERTUCCIO is pressing forward) Back! or the grooms
Shall score thy hunch to motley. (he closes the door)

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: How now, sirrah,
Call you this marshalling?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I am right served!
I forgot fools in silks should take precedence
Of fools in motley!—Lead the way, my lords!

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: Look, here comes Malatesta.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Ha!—but stay
To hear me gird at him! You call me bitter;
Now you shall see how merciful I've been.

sp.speaker: Ascolti.
sp.l: Waste not your ears on him—the Duke awaits us
Beside his beauty—metal more attractive
Than this curst word-catcher.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: Aye, aye—let's in.

div.stage: Exeunt ORDELAFFI and ASCOLTI.
BERTUCCIO goes hastily to R. entrance Enter FRANCESCA.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Now, now, Madonna—have you proof enough?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Mountains of proof on proof—if proof were needed—
But had disproof come with them, and not proof,
'Tis all too late—

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I have drugged their wine—
They will sleep sound to-night! (she retires up)

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (aside) Choose woman's hands
You that would have grim work nimbly despatched!
Here's Malatesta! Looking black as night.
So, Lord, I hope you liked your waking news!
Now—now—to gloat over his agony!

div.stage: Enter MALATESTA, L.

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: (not seeing the Duchess) Ha—knave—I'd see the duchess!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (looking at him curiously) Marvellous!

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: To think that they can make such caps
To hide all trace of them—

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: Of what, knave?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Horns—

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: Rascal!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I hope your lordship had good rest?
And that my lady, too, slept undisturbed.

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: What mean you, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Nay—strain not so hard
To keep it down—You are among friends here—
A grievous loss, no doubt—But at your age
You could scarce look to keep her to yourself—
Others have lost wives too—Poor knaves who thought
To stick in their thrum caps jewels that caught
The eyes of nobles—needs were they must yield
Daughters—or wives—

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: Art mad, or drunk, or both?
My errand's to thy mistress—not to thee.
Where is she?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: (coming down) Here, my lord! (they talk apart)

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: He bears it bravely.
But wounds will bleed under an iron corslet:
And how his must be bleeding! For he loved her—
The whole Court vouches it—as old men love:

div.l: Husbanding their spent fires into a heat,
The fiercer, that it has short time to burn.
div.stage: (FRANCESCA and MALATESTA come forward)

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You say your lady slept not here, last night,
But at Ceséna?

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: Or the devil's in't.
I saw her safe bestowed there: I can trust
My own eyes—or still better, my own bolts.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (amazed and aside) Is this old man, too, of Manfredi's council,
To cheat his wife?

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: I little thought to bring her back so soon;
But, on your summons, I have straight recalled her.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (breaking in eagerly) And she is here: hold him to that, Madonna.

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: Malapert dog!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Pardon his licensed tongue.
I fain would see the lady.

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: (bowing) You shall see her;
I have not far to fetch her.

div.stage: Exit, L.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (furiously) 'Tis a lie!
A cursed lie! to hide his own foul shame!
Believe him not!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: But if he bring the lady?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (laughing) Aye, if he bring the lady, then believe him!
(aside) He robs me of my right—taking his wrong
With outward show of calm. Mine turned my brain:
I looked to see him mad—or drive him so!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: (within) More wine, knave!

div.stage: Enter a PAGE from C. door, passes out, L.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ginevra, or another, what of that?
The wrong's the same—why not the same revenge?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: The same to you, but not the same to me!
I tell you Malatesta's wife sits yonder—
Sits at your husband's side: I saw her—I—
Borne off last night! I saw. There is no faith
In eyes, or ears, or truth, if 'twere not she!

div.stage: Re-enter MALATESTA, L., with GINEVRA—BERTUCCIO's back is towards the door.

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: Madam, my wife!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (turning, in amaze) Ginevra here! then who
Was that they carried from her bed last night?
Who is't sits yonder?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Tell me, gracious lady,
Where did you sleep last night?

sp.speaker: Ginev.
sp.l: Where I scarce thought
To leave so soon, your highness; in Ceséna,
Within my husband's castle.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Pardon, madam,
That I have set you on a hurried journey,
Still more that I have wronged you in my thoughts!

l.stage: (passing her hand over her brow—laughter heard within)

sp.l: (aside) They laugh! laugh on, my lord, while it is time.

sp.speaker: Ginev.
sp.l: Wilt please you grant me audience: you shall hear
To the minute how my hours went yesterday,
Down to this moment.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Come out in the air;
I stifle within hearing of their mirth.
(to BERTUCCIO) Stay here! see that the other 'scape me not!

div.stage: Exeunt FRANCESCO and GINEVRA, L.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: The other! Not Ginevra? (to MALATESTA) Good, my lord,
Your wife slept at Ceséna, yet her chamber
Was not untenanted last night, I'll swear!

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: And so thou might'st, yet break no oath.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Who slept in't?

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: I know not, ask Dell' Aquila; 'twas he
Brought me the lady; craving shelter for her
From some great danger.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: But you saw her face?

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: And if I did—think'st thou I'd trust her name
To thy ass-ears?

div.stage: Exit MALATESTA, L.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Fooled—mocked of my revenge!
The sweetest morsel on't whip't from my teeth!
Oh, I could brain myself with my own bauble!

div.stage: Enter DELL'AQUILA, L.

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Well met, Bertuccio;
I've sought thee since this morning, nay, since midnight.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: For a matter much concerns thy peace.
Thou hast a daughter. (BERTUCCIO starts) How I know thou hast
Matters not to my story.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (hastily) Hush—hush—hush!
If you know this, as you are Christian man,
And poet—poets should have softer hearts
Than courts and camps breed now-a-days—Oh, keep
The knowledge to yourself!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: It is too late.
Torelli knew it—had set wolfish eyes
On her—

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Well?—well?

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Had rung her beauty's praise
Here in the court. Thou hast no friends here.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (eagerly) Well?

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: They plotted how to lure thee from the house;
And, in thy absence, to surprise her window,
And bear her off! They bound me by an oath
To keep it secret from thee—not from her.
I swore to save her, or to lose myself;
So found a desperate means of speech with her,—
And warned her of her danger.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Thanks—thanks—thanks!
But only warned her!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Placed her too in safety.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Oh, heaven! where?

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: In the house of Malatesta.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (hoarsely) My child in Malatesta's house last night!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Secure—even in the countess's own chamber!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (with a wild cry) My child! my child! wronged! murdered!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Ha! by whom?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (wildly) By me! by me! Her father—her own father!

div.l: That would have grasped heaven's vengeance, and have drawn
The bolt on my own head, and her's—and her's!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I counselled the undoing
Of Malatesta's wife—I stood and watched,
And laughed for joy, and held the ladder for them,
And all the while, 'twas my own innocent child!
Look not so scared—'tis true—I am not mad!
She's here—now—in their clutches! (laughter within) Hark—they laugh!
'Tis the hyænas o'er their prey—my child!—
And I stand here and cannot lift a hand!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Here's mine, and my sword too!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Oh! what were that
Against their felon blades?

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Ha! there's the duchess!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (shrieks) True—true! what aid? I had forgotten her!
sp.stage: (drawing AQUILA to him and whispering hoarsely)
sp.l: Man—she has drugged their wine—the bony Death
Plays cupbearer to them; if she drinks, she dies!

div.stage: Enter a PAGE with wine, L.
div.l: Look—look. Perchance, that is the very wine!
div.stage: (he runs between the PAGE and the door, and assumes the fool's manner)
div.l: Halt there! for the fool's toll. No wine goes in

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Out, knave—stand aside—

div.stage: (BERTUCCIO snatches the flagons from the salver)

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: 'Tis forfeit by the law!

div.stage: (The PAGE tries to recover the wine—in the struggle BERTUCCIO pretends to upset the flagons by accident, and the wine is poured out upon the stage)

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Thy back shall bleed
To make it up. Now must I go fetch more—
And brook the cellarer's chiding for thy folly.

div.stage: Enter TORELLI, L.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: (to AQUILA) If he goes in—could we but enter with him.

div.l: A word of mine might save her from the poison.
div.stage: (BERTUCCIO gets between him and the door)

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Good day, sir poet—stand aside, sir fool.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: You are going in?

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Aye!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: There's a shrewd hiatus
Needs filling at the table. You have War
And Love, but lacking Poetry and Folly,
War is but butchery, and Love goes lame.
Tuck us beneath your wings, sweet Baldassare,
And you'll be trebly welcome!
sp.stage: (seizing him by one arm, and motioning DELL'AQUILA to take the other)

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: The duke for once has shut his doors against
Both Poetry and Folly. He is closeted
For grave affairs.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Tush—tell me not, sweet gossip.
Why, man—I know that there's a petticoat—
And more, I know the wearer.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Thou!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: You've lost
The rarest sport. Ascolti and Ordelaffi
Have had their will of me. For once I'll own
You've turned the tables fairly on the fool!
That our Ginevra should be Fiordelisa,
And poor Bertuccio not know! Ha, ha!
Oh, excellent! It was a sleight of hand
I shall remember to my dying day!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Nay, an thou tak'st it so—

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: How should I take it?
Besides the pleasantness of it, there's the honor.
Think, my poor daughter in the duke's high favor.
Why, there are counts by scores, had pawned their scutcheons
To come into such grace. I warrant, now,
You thought I'd swear, and storm, and rend you all,
So shut me out. But, lo you, I am merry,
And so shall she be, if you'll let me in?—
But let me in—I'll school the silly wench;—
Teach her what honor she has come to thank
The gracious duke, and play the merriest antics.

div.l: You'll swear you never saw me in such fooling—

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Why now; the fool's grown wise!
I'll tell the duke—perchance he'll let thee in.

div.stage: Exit TORELLI, C.
(BERTUCCIO, exhausted by his emotions, falls into a chair, and writhes convulsively).

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: Lives hang on minutes here. Said you the duchess
Had mixed the poison—or but meant to mix it?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: There it is, man—I know not which. Ev'n now
Death may be busy at her lips. Once in,
In my mad antics, I might spurn the board,
And spill the flagons, as I did e'en now;—
But here I'm helpless. Oh, Beelzebub!
Inspire them with desire to see a father
Make laughter of the undoing of his child!
Ha! some one comes. They'll let me in!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: (at the door) The duke
Will none of thy ape's tricks.

div.stage: (C. door opens)
(he retires closing the door—BERTUCCIO wrings his hands and screams)

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: (rushing forward) What ho! Torelli!
And you within, you, my lord duke, 'fore all!
I do proclaim you cowards, ruffians, beasts!
Come out, if you be men, and drive my challenge
Back in my throat, if you've one heart among you!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: You speak to men—they're fiends!

sp.speaker: Aquila.
sp.l: No hope, no hope!
Yes! here's the duchess, she's a woman still—

div.stage: Enter FRANCESCA and GINEVRA, L.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Madam, and you, too—(to GINEVRA) Plotting your undoing,
I've compassed the destruction of my child,
The daughter that I loved more than my life.
'Twas she they seized last night, and she's in there.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Your child?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: From death, if not wrong worse than death,
You still may save her. Have the doors burst open

div.l: You can command here—next the duke. If not,
At least (aside to her) forbear the poison!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: (aside to him). 'Tis too late—
The wine was here!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Then this alone remains.

l.stage: (he rushes up to the door and shouts)

sp.l: Come forth, my lords!
The duke's life—all your lives
Hang by a thread! Come forth—all! For your lives!

div.stage: (TORELLI, ASCOLTI and ORDELAFFI appear at the door)

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: Ha! Who did the deed?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I!—drink not—for your lives!

div.stage: (they are rushing upon him, drawing their swords)

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: He lies! 'Twas I! (a shriek is heard within)

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: My child! my child!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: (who has turned back at the sound, flinging the door wide open) Look to the duke, my lords!

div.stage: (as the doors are flung open, the interior of the inner room is seen, with the DUKE senseless on his seat, and FIORDELISA lying at his feet—TORELLI, ASCOLTI, and ORDELAFFI support the DUKE—BERTUCCIO and DELL'AQUILA rush up to FIORDELISA)

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Too late! Too late!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: He's dead!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Before all men,
I'll answer this!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Before heaven's judgment seat,
How shall I answer this? (pointing to FIORDELISA—DELL'AQUILA has brought FIORDELISA forward—BERTUCCIO takes her in his arms)
Dead!—dead!—My bird!
My lily flower!—Gone to thy last account,
All sinless as thou wert. My fool's revenge,
Ends but in this! Cold! cold! (putting his hand on her heart) Ha! Yes! a beat!
(putting his lips to her mouth) A breath! a full deep breath! She lives! she lives!
Say some of you—She drank not! and I'll bless
The man that says so—yea, so pray for him
As saints ne'er prayed! She breathes—still—Hark! hark!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: (faintly) Father!

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: She never drank!
Thou hast her pure as when
She kissed thy lips last night!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Oh, bless you, bless you!
She lives—lives—lives! Leave us to pray together.

sp.speaker: Torelli.
sp.l: (to FRANCESCA) Madam, you are our prisoner—the duke
Lies foully murdered.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ha! what call you "foully?"
Who but myself can estimate my wrongs?
For those who stand, like him, past reach of justice,
Vengeance takes Justice's sharp sword.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: No, no!
Vengeance is hellish!—Justice is from heaven!
Look, Guido Malatesta, I am he
Whose wife, long years ago, you stole from him—
I am Antonio Bordiga!

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.l: You?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I thirsted for revenge—for that I wrought
Upon the duke to carry off your wife—
Your innocent Ginevra;—seeking that,
See to what verge of terrible disaster
I brought my own dear daughter!—seeking that,
I've compassed the duke's death, whose blood must lie
Still on my head!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: (proudly) I take it upon mine!
My father, Giovanni Bentivoglio
Stands at your gate, in arms!—Let who will, question
Francesca Bentivoglio of this deed!

sp.speaker: Fiord.
sp.l: Father!—let's pray for her!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: For her!—for me!
We need it both! Ah, thou said'st well, my child!
Vengeance is not man's attribute—but heaven's!
I have usurped it. (hiding his face in her bosom)
Pray—oh, pray for me.

div.stage: ASCOLTI, ORDELAFFI, TORELLI, round the DUKE. DELL'AQUILA. MALA. GINEVRA. BERT. FIORD. FRAN. R. L.
